title: 104_s1855
content:
The Act titled "Securities and Exchange Commission Fee Reduction Act of 1996" aims to reduce registration fees. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to require payment of registration fees to the Commission at the time of filing a registration statement, with a minimum fee not exceeding $100. The Commission will publish fee rates in the Federal Register annually. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to require registration fees paid to the Commission at the time of filing a registration statement. The fee rate is $200 per $1,000,000 before 2002 and $182 per $1,000,000 from 2002 onwards. Fees collected are deposited as general revenues of the Treasury. The Securities Act of 1933 amended to require registration fees paid to the Commission at the time of filing a registration statement. The fee rate is $200 per $1,000,000 before 2002 and $182 per $1,000,000 from 2002 onwards. Fees collected are deposited as general revenues of the Treasury. Offsetting collection fees are determined based on the maximum aggregate price of subject securities offered, with rates decreasing over fiscal years 1997-2000 and reaching $0 in fiscal year 2001 and beyond. The Securities Act of 1933 amended registration fees paid to the Commission. Fees collected are deposited as general revenues. If no regular appropriation is enacted, the Commission continues to collect fees at the previous year's rate. SEC. 31 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to address transaction fees. SEC. 31 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to address transaction fees for national securities exchanges. Each exchange must pay a fee based on the aggregate dollar amount of securities sales, with rates set at $33 per $1,000,000 for most securities and $25 per $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 onwards. Fees collected will go to the Treasury as general revenue. Each national securities association must pay the Commission fees based on the aggregate dollar amount of off-exchange trades of exchange-registered securities. The rates are set at $33 per $1,000,000 for most securities and $25 per $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 onwards. Each national securities association must pay the Commission fees based on off-exchange trades of last-sale-reported securities. The fees collected will be deposited as general revenue of the Treasury. The Commission or a registered national securities association must report last sale data and pay fees based on off-exchange trades of last-sale-reported securities. Fee rates range from $12 to $25 for different fiscal years, with limitations on fee collection before October 1, 2001. Fees collected by the Commission from off-exchange trades of last-sale-reported securities are subject to limitations based on fiscal years, with specific deposit and credit requirements for excess amounts. The Securities and Exchange Commission collects fees from off-exchange trades of last-sale-reported securities, with limitations based on fiscal years. If a regular appropriation is not enacted at the start of a fiscal year, the Commission continues to collect fees at the previous year's rate. Payment of fees must be made by specific dates for transactions occurring during certain periods. The Securities and Exchange Commission may exempt certain securities sales from fees if it serves the public interest. No fees are charged for low-volume equity transactions during specific trading hours. The Commission is required to publish fee information in the Federal Register. The Securities and Exchange Commission will publish fee rates applicable for each fiscal year in the Federal Register. The amendment made by subsection (a) will apply to securities transactions from October 1, 1996, with exceptions for off-exchange trades of last sale reported transactions. Exchanges and brokers must make payments under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 on March 15, 1997. SEC. 4. TIME FOR PAYMENT.

Amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to specify the time for fee payment in relation to filing statements.

SEC. 5. ELIMINATION OF UNNECESSARY FEES.

Fees authorized by this Act replace any fees the SEC can collect under section 9701 of title 31, United States Code.
